","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BEIL0001","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEIL0001 - Graphic Design for the Built Environment","description":"

This elective is open to students in the Architecture, Interior Architecture, Landscape Architecture, Industrial Design, Computational Design, Construction Management and Planning disciplines. The seamless integration of the products of graphic design into commercial and urban spaces, at both the intimate and public scales,is expected of Built Environment designers. This course aims to give students the skills to attempt a basic level of graphic design and to become familiar with the wide range of graphic techniques and materials available. At the end of the course the student will understand techniques for integrating graphic materials into buildings and be able to brief a graphic designer for the most complex of tasks. Material covered in the course will include the basics of typography, layout design and colour. Techniques for printing, including those for incorporating images into a range of building materials will be introduced. In addition topics such as digital reproduction technologies, digital and colour systems, paper engineering, diagram design and three-dimensional graphic representation will be included. Concepts of corporate identity and marketing within the context of the exhibition/public space/corporate environment will be dealt with. Discussion in class will include topics such as Venturi’s “Building as Duck”. Students will undertake a range of activities including exercises in interdisciplinary project management and planning. This provides the students with the opportunity to observe the delineation of responsibilities of other disciplines statement of duties which are applied to the major way-finding assignments worth 40% of their final marks.

contentlets.description: This elective is open to students in the Architecture, Interior Architecture, Landscape Architecture, Industrial Design, Computational Design, Construction Management and Planning disciplines. The seamless integration of the products of graphic design into commercial and urban spaces, at both the intimate and public scales,is expected of Built Environment designers. This course aims to give students the skills to attempt a basic level of graphic design and to become familiar with the wide range of graphic techniques and materials available. At the end of the course the student will understand techniques for integrating graphic materials into buildings and be able to brief a graphic designer for the most complex of tasks. Material covered in the course will include the basics of typography, layout design and colour. Techniques for printing, including those for incorporating images into a range of building materials will be introduced. In addition topics such as digital reproduction technologies, digital and colour systems, paper engineering, diagram design and three-dimensional graphic representation will be included. Concepts of corporate identity and marketing within the context of the exhibition/public space/corporate environment will be dealt with. Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEIL0003 - Built Environment Annual Design Competition","description":"

BE Design Competitions is one of four streams of the Built Environment Interdisciplinary Learning (BEIL) initiative offered by the Faculty of Built Environment.


The BE Annual Design Competition is an opportunity for BE students with at least 96UoC completed, to work on complex 'real life' projects in interdisciplinary teams with leading design professionals, industry and community partners. These competitions will offer an opportunity for students to learn from and interact with industry and community partners, and to showcase the resulting work via exhibition opportunities throughout the subsequent year.  The competition project will vary each year and may be taught by different undergraduate programs each year. The course will be taught in a studio style format, encouraging collaborative group work and group learning.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0cbae533dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Preliminary Concept Development","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will work in interdisciplinary teams to develop design solutions that address the competition brief.

In this phase of the competition students will develop an understanding of key issues and key site and contextual considerations and develop a report on this, making recommendations for their subsequent designs.

contentlets.description:
BE Design Competitions is one of four streams of the Built Environment Interdisciplinary Learning (BEIL) initiative offered by the Faculty of Built Environment.

The BE Annual Design Competition is an opportunity for BE students with at least 96UoC completed, to work on complex 'real life' projects in interdisciplinary teams with leading design professionals, industry and community partners. These competitions will offer an opportunity for students to learn from and interact with industry and community partners, and to showcase the resulting work via exhibition opportunities throughout the subsequent year.  The competition project will vary each year and may be taught by different undergraduate programs each year. The course will be taught in a studio style format, encouraging collaborative group work and group learning.
contentlets.title: Built Environment Annual Design Competition

contentlets.description:
BE Design Competitions is one of four streams of the Built Environment Interdisciplinary Learning (BEIL) initiative offered by the Faculty of Built Environment.

Opportunities for BE students to participate in design competitions and bids materialise throughout the year. These opportunities can translate well into interdisciplinary courses and will be offered in the BEIL competition stream when they are suitable for students from at least four different programs. Students will have completed at least 96UoC in order to be eligible to enrol. Students will work on complex 'real life' projects in interdisciplinary teams with leading design professionals, industry and community partners. These courses will enhance skills needed in professional practice, offering an opportunity for students to learn from and interact with industry and community partners, and to showcase their work via exhibitions. The project or focus at the centre of these courses will vary each time it is run and may be taught by different undergraduate programs. The course will be taught in a studio style format, encouraging collaborative group work and group learning.

People, Place, Design provides an introduction to the extensive body of environment-behaviour research and theory on people’s relationship to place. Students will gain an understanding of the needs of specific users in the design of public spaces in which they live, work and play. Individual perceptions of shared and personal space, universal design and social inclusion will be explored, along with considering how planning and design contribute to social and environmental sustainability in communities. Most of the ideas and concepts discussed will be relevant to all environments and all types of design but for this course the focus will be on public spaces and environments in the public domain.
The course will look at concepts that relate to people and their needs. This will include special population groups, such as children and young people, the elderly, people with disabilities, people from different cultural backgrounds. It will also look at different environments through a social lens including the public domain, open space and parks in urban settings; the streetscape as a significant environment for interaction and ‘liveability’ of a city; environmental design factors that enable or discourage participation and sustainability in communities. The third part of the course will look at the implications of using an environment-behaviour lens as part of design and planning practice, discussing concepts such as public involvement and participatory planning and design and providing opportunities for the class to engage in some of these processes and methods.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b6f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96197d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: How does your profession impact people?","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Self reflection assignment- students reflect on the many ways their profession makes an impact potentially on the everyday lives of people.

Feedback on your assessment tasks will be given 2 weeks after submission. It will be written feedback on individual assignments. There will be plenty of opportunity to question feedback during class time and by email during the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"32f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"76f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961958","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2ef599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961945","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Two in-class activities centred on behaviour mapping and public involvement","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Feedback on your assessment tasks will be given orally through the in-class discussion. There will be plenty of opportunity to question feedback during class time.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"32f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"76f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961958","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"66f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96194a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Social challenges: Environmental solutions","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Students will work in interdisciplinary teams of 3-4 people with at least 3 disciplines in each team.They willl complete part 1 individually and part 2 as a group. Students will choose a pressing social issue (from a list of topics), research it, understand it and recognise the role that the physical environment plays in it. In part 2, the interdisciplinary groups develop an environmental or technological intervention that would assist the issue.

Feedback on part 1 will be given 2 weeks after submission. It will be written feedback on the individual assignments. The feedback on part 2 will be attached to Moodle for each group. There will be plenty of opportunity to question feedback during class time and by email during the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"32f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"76f599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961958","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7ef599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"baf599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"aef599bbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96194e","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BEIL0005.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Elective","description":"

This elective is open to all undergraduate students in BE, who are in their third year or above. Students from other Faculties may also enrol. The course provides students with a "service-learning" experience working in an interdisciplinary project context on a challenging social issue. The service-learning approach gives relevance to students' learning by acknowledging that they bring prior knowledge, experience and skills to the project and provides the opportunity to apply and integrate that previous learning to a real-world problem. In the process, the requirements of the project will challenge students to research additional information, share their findings with each other and creatively synthesise a design solution that responds to all aspects of the client's brief.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"62e774fbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Background Research and Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Depending on the project, this will include a literature review and/or site analysis; to demonstrate an understanding of the issue(s) and the project site/context (Individual work); written feedback

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"52e774fbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0ae774fbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Writing a project brief and forming a team","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Teams will be assembled; working together, a project brief will be written and presented that responds to the issues and site constraints/ opportunities; within the framework of a project template that will be provided; written feedback

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1ae774fbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9ee774fbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dae774fbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"42e774fbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design proposals, development and final presentation to client","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BEIL0007","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEIL0007 - Sustainable Design Thinking","description":"

BEIL0007 is offered as part of the suite of courses under the Built Environment Interdisciplinary Learning (BEIL) initiative. This course introduces both design and non-design students from the Built Environment degree programs to 'design thinking': a creative problem solving process that involves empathic understanding of users, problem reframing and definition, idea generation, and prototyping and testing of ideas, as prerequisites to arriving at meaningful, responsible and sustainable solutions in response to real-world problems. Weekly activities build capabilities in using ideation and innovation strategies to achieve more imaginative and human-focused outcomes. The course culminates with a 'sustainable innovation challenge' that integrates the specialized skills of the cross-disciplinary student teams. In the teamwork that occurs, students are expected to contribute the unique insights, theories, methods, communication forms, and other prior skills from their own academic specialization, in order to enrich the learning of their teams as they cooperate and collaborate on assessment tasks.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1b83a497db63a450be4672f5f3961980","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Task 2 Individual Ideation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Task 2 Ideation consists of the Design Thinking phases of 'Ideation' and 'Prototyping'. At this phase, students will be expected to individually brainstorm creative responses to their One Planet Living Challenge and submit the most innovative idea as a 'napkin pitch' and an 'elevator pitch'.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1383a497db63a450be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1783a497db63a450be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1b83a497db63a450be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1b83a497db63a450be4672f5f3961984","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Task 3 Group Pitching","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Task 3 of the One Planet Living Challenge project will be done as a group effort. Group submissions will be assessed for individual inputs via Moodle’s Team Evaluation tool. This plug-in scales the group grade up or down for each group member to reflect their personal contribution. A non-completion penalty of 10% applies to those who do not answer the Team Evaluation questionnaire. In this assessment task, students will collaboratively find an economically viable, technologically feasible, and user-desirable solution to their One Planet Living Challenge, and pitch their unique value proposition to the class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1383a497db63a450be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1783a497db63a450be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1b83a497db63a450be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5b83e497db63a450be4672f5f3961977","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Task 1 Individual Empathy","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Task 1 consists of the Design Thinking phases of 'Understanding' and 'Empathy'. At this phase students will be expected to individually collect background information and existing solutions to their One Planet Living Challenge.They will also 'empathize' by interviewing people in class about their everyday actions towards sustainability.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1383a497db63a450be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1783a497db63a450be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1b83a497db63a450be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6b83e497db63a450be4672f5f396197e","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BEIL0007.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

In BEIL0008 Design Project Management students will explore how each of the Faculty’s professional disciplines, working together & individually, can project manage the design process & the project management knowledge areas of design scope, time & cost for a Client’s vision for their buildings, to make it a reality. “From vision & ideas comes reality”.

The Course is also about effective & efficient teamwork, group decision making & team communications that are so essential to successfully project manage a Client’s design to meet their vision. Students will explore & integrate multiple perspectives from different built environment disciplines & expertise. Lectures will introduce topics & industry experts will discuss current practice in the design project management.

Students will discuss interdisciplinary design project management processes in online learning assignments, independently explore & document areas of project management design scope, design time & design cost while working co-operatively in interdisciplinary Major Assignment teams.

Individual learning reflection is assessed weekly during the tutorials (Total 10x2% = 20%). Feedback is provided immediately by the lecturer and/or tutors.

This major assignment documentation (total 40%) is a consultant report on a selected project on how you will manage the design procurement, design scope and design time  (11,000 words maximum) when you are the leaders of your adopted professions in our industry, in 5 to 7 years’ time.

More Information about the Consultant Report such as structure, format, and assessment will be provided on Moodle system. (20% individual contribution will be assessed, and 20% group contribution.)

Feedback will be provided in writing after the marking process.

contentlets.description:
In BEIL0008 Design Project Management students will explore how each of the Faculty’s professional disciplines, working together & individually, can project manage the design process & the project management knowledge areas of design scope, time & cost for a Client’s vision for their buildings, to make it a reality. “From vision & ideas comes reality”.

The Course is also about effective & efficient teamwork, group decision making & team communications that are so essential to successfully project manage a Client’s design to meet their vision. Students will explore & integrate multiple perspectives from different built environment disciplines & expertise. Lectures will introduce topics & industry experts will discuss current practice in the design project management.

Students will discuss interdisciplinary design project management processes in online learning assignments, independently explore & document areas of project management design scope, design time & design cost while working co-operatively in interdisciplinary Major Assignment teams.
contentlets.title: Design Project Management - Vision to Reality

Exhibition Design: Transforming Temporary Space","description":"

Exhibition design is inherently interdisciplinary with practitioners coming from a wide variety of design disciplines. The domain of the designer includes corporate trade shows and events, curated museum displays, travelling exhibitions and the emerging area of short term ‘pop up’ spaces. In this course students will learn about the the history and evolution of exhibition and display as a cultural marker in societies; the palette of materials and tools at the designer’s disposal. Students will also be shown a broad range of case studies and cosider a variety of possible design outcomes. Assignments will involve interdisciplinary group work, undertaking tasks to build understanding of the issues in professional exhibition design. This course is ideal for those undertaking a design focused degree.


 


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fe5cdcfadb43d850eb6b147a3a9619cd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Exhibition Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Description – The Exhibition Design demonstrates knowledge of the chosen exhibition typology and develop a resolved response to the requirements of the chosen brief. Students build a detailed representation of the refined design that was presented in Assessment 2, rendered with materials, branding and lighting with display items and figures to scale. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"325c103edb43d850eb6b147a3a96191b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b65cdcfadb43d850eb6b147a3a9619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ba5cdcfadb43d850eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4f5c103edb43d850eb6b147a3a961943","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Research Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

The Research Portfolio demonstrates knowledge of the chosen exhibition typology and builds awareness of the design issues involved in a professional exhibition. Students participate in a range of in-class research and design tasks that are low-stakes progress submissions to support their understanding of the field of exhibition design, the iterative design process and the translation of strategic ideas into spatial outcomes. 

\n

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"325c103edb43d850eb6b147a3a96191b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"be5cdcfadb43d850eb6b147a3a9619cf","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"875c103edb43d850eb6b147a3a961925","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Exhibition Pitch","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Description – The Exhibition Pitch demonstrates an understanding and awareness of how to manipulate a display space using design elements and principles in attracting, leading and influencing audiences in an exhibition environment. Students individually produce one cohesive proposal for an exhibition design that addresses the requirements of the chosen brief.

Our Built Environment Faculty is fundamentally about creating value. Each of the Built Environment professional disciplines strives to produce value for their clients, their communities, their society and themselves. But we rarely examine how we"manage this value creation", define"the value for whom" and prioritise the often"conflicting values being created" in our professional life and work. In BEIL0010 Creating Value for Built Environment Clients, we will explore how each of our professional disciplines, working together and individually, can maximise the value we create for our Clients, our communities, our society and ourselves. The course is also about effective teamwork, group decision making and team communications that is so essential to successful value creation.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7d2175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online quiz associated with tutorial workshops","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

Four online quizzes will be on a range of course contents, completed within the tutorial period by individual student. Total 35% (individual work).

Feedback will be provided immediately on Moodle, and further clarification can be soughted from the tutors if necessary. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"352175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a92175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final consultant report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The final consultant report should be about 11000 words, and covers all sections as given in the draft consultant report, plus attachment of the team meeting minutes.  Total 40% (10% group work and 30% individual work).

Written feedback will be provided to students.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"352175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"712175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b92175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f52175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a92175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Draft consultation report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

A 6000-word draft consultation report to be submitted by each group for feedback before producing the final report.

Each team is responsible for the following sections: Document Control Sheet, Executive Summary; Client strategic objectives & key performance indicators for the Project; Recommendations; Bibliography; etc. Individual student will be responsible for documenting one chapter relevant to one of the disciplines. Total 15% (10% group work and 5% individual work).

Written feedback will be provided to students. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"352175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"712175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f52175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e12175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Consultant report presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Assume you are presenting to the Directors of the Client entity of your Project who have commissioned your team to prepare the Consultant Report. You must address four (4) key strategic objectives that your team has identified that achieves Value for the Client from the Project.

Each team will have 12-15 minutes to complete your Team presentations and a further 5 minutes to answer questions from the Assessment Panel. Total 10% (group work).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"352175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"712175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f52175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e12175b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BEIL0010.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Healthy Planning","description":"

Healthy Planning is an inter-disciplinary elective for senior students studying to be built environment and health professionals. The course focuses on the ways in which built, natural and socio-cultural environments inhibit on the one hand, and on the other, enhance and sustain the physical and mental health of contemporary communities. The course explores the relationship between the urban environment and current chronic health issues facing modern society – particularly lifestyle related health problems associated with obesity and low rates of physical activity – for example, diabetes, heart disease, some cancers and depression. Research and theoretical issues which draw planning and health together are presented using specific case studies. Classes involve a mixture of lectures, participant discussion, presentations and strategic engagement with healthy planning tools. The course includes a significant field work project.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b600ba51db417c10fe4b322af49619fb","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"The Neighbourhood Audit","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This assignment has two components – a neighbourhood audit and assessment of green open space. You will undertake an audit of your local neighbourhood using a prescribed audit instrument, reflecting on how your neighbourhood broadly supports your health and wellbeing as part of everyday living. You will then consider and document (using text and images) the qualities of the green environments that are easily accessible to you, as well as reflect on the ways in which these spaces support healthy behaviours that are essential for your physical and mental wellbeing

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b200ba51db417c10fe4b322af49619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b600ba51db417c10fe4b322af49619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"be00ba51db417c10fe4b322af49619fd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0fc0f691db417c10fe4b322af4961902","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"My Day: Personal health reflections","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

You will record your ‘day on a plate’, reflecting on the extent to which your food intake is supportive of your health and well-being as part of everyday living (a series of questions will guide your reflections). You will also record your daily activities where you move for both recreation and transport – how does your environment facilitate and/or hinder you being active?

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b600ba51db417c10fe4b322af49619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b600ba51db417c10fe4b322af49619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"be00ba51db417c10fe4b322af49619fd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"84b07291db417c10fe4b322af496191e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This task will assist you to synthesise your learning across the entire course – material from lectures, key readings and activities will be included. This assignment will be set in collaboration with the Faculty Teaching Team – details to be released when they come to hand.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b200ba51db417c10fe4b322af49619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b600ba51db417c10fe4b322af49619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b600ba51db417c10fe4b322af49619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"be00ba51db417c10fe4b322af49619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"be00ba51db417c10fe4b322af49619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f7e07291db417c10fe4b322af496192a","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BEIL0011.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEIL0014 - Digital Making","description":"

'Digital Making' builds on the advanced knowledge generated and documented within CODE2230 - Human-Machine Interaction, CODE2250 - Advanced Digital Fabrication and CODE2270 - Design Information Management, and represent the completion of the 'Applied Level' stream of the Computational Design degree. The course introduces and critiques design by making through digital fabrication technologies and advanced prototyping. Students will be provided with the conceptual understanding, technical skills and critical thinking methods required to apply and review skills in digital making as a system that connects design to fabrication. The students performance will be evaluated with respect to their progressive work developed in preparation for or during the studio activities. Students will employ a range of verbal and multimedia communication skills to represent and deliver their design decisions and prototyping results with professionalism, clarity and purpose.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEIL0016 - Renewing the Urban Environment","description":"



This course will focus on precincts and public and/or community based projects that have the potential to catalyse revitalisation and/or renewal in urban environments. It will explore themes from a variety of disciplinary perspectives with a view to demonstrating the complex nature of existing urban environments and the importance of a collaborative interdisciplinary approach. Each course will have real-world client and focus on a specific, place-based issue or project. Students will work together in teams to undertake site analysis, research relevant precedents and critically apply learning to provide recommendations and/or solutions.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BEIL0017","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEIL0017 - Business Start Up","description":"

This course offers those intending to start up their own creative business an understanding of the essential business requirements for setting up and running a small creative enterprise. Students will learn how to communicate with other disciplines and understand what other disciplines do, understand the practical, legal and organisational aspects of running a professional design practice. It will teach basic business skills, what business structure to adopt, how to produce a marketing strategy, write a design brief for the client, present a fee proposal and how to invoice for the various design activities. It is practical and outcome orientated and at the successful conclusion the student should be able to open the doors to their business.    

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"da8583f81b046410d5fb0fabdc4bcb48","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Professional Relationships","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Professional Relationships

Students work in multidisciplinary groups to develop an innovative response to an industry brief. Groups present their idea and business model in the form of a pitch.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d28583f81b046410d5fb0fabdc4bcb4a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d68583f81b046410d5fb0fabdc4bcb4b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"de8583f81b046410d5fb0fabdc4bcb4a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"de8583f81b046410d5fb0fabdc4bcb4b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3d1bf7b8dbc0a090eb6b147a3a96194e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Business Identity","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

Business Identity

Individually, students design and prepare their business identity and the accompanying collateral. Supported by course resources and lectures, students will conduct their own research into the appropriate marketing and branding strategies to communicate their products/services to a target market.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d68583f81b046410d5fb0fabdc4bcb4b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"de8583f81b046410d5fb0fabdc4bcb4a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"de8583f81b046410d5fb0fabdc4bcb4b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"89aaf7b8dbc0a090eb6b147a3a961949","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Business Management","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Business Management

Students will provide detailed information on the organisation and running of their business. This involves attention to the management and storage of data, sound reasoning for the selection of a business structure, and clear plans for record keeping. Students are expected to conduct their own research which will be complemented by course resources and lectures.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d68583f81b046410d5fb0fabdc4bcb4b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"de8583f81b046410d5fb0fabdc4bcb4a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"de8583f81b046410d5fb0fabdc4bcb4b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a0dabbb8dbc0a090eb6b147a3a96195a","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BEIL0017.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEIL0018 - Kirigami Architectural Principles & Creative Paper Engineering","description":"

Kirigami  is a variation of origami that includes cutting of the paper (from Japanese "kiru" = to cut, "kami" = paper)


How can flat surfaces be transformed into useful three-dimensional structures? 


Kirigami patterns can be robustly manipulated into a variety of three-dimensional shapes by folding and cutting a flat surface into complex target configurations.


The course is designed to foster knowledge, understanding and skills that will assist the student with both future courses and professional design practice. Each class incorporates a range of teaching and learning strategies including demonstrations, studio exercises, hands-on making, and discussion. The basis of the exercises and assignments use folding and cutting to interpret the principles of each drawing skill: Orthographic/parallel folds, Axonometric/equal angle folds, Isometric/unequal angle folds and Parametric/pleat folds applied to span and parabola.


Skills covered in the course range from techniques of hand folding and physical model-building to presentation strategies and display systems. Weekly demonstrations and visual presentations address the conventions associated with modes of Architecture, Industrial Design, Interior and Landscape Architecture representation and their capacity to convey ideas.


Students, using DesignLab resources, classify the basic properties, appropriate application and performance of construction materials, products, components, and assemblies, including their environmental impact and reuse.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b260c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a961935","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Parametric folds applied to spans and parabola","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Learning from natural systems as a means of developing structural efficiencies, students adapt Tessellation exercises to Parametric modelling. These exercises are applied to landscape architecture using contour folds to create a diorama.

This assignment, developed from week-to-week exercises, involve student participation in the lectures and tutorials, allowing feedback and constructive criticism of their work in progress. The informal feedback assists students interpreting the assignment and achieving assessment objectives which evaluate their demonstrated ability to translate drawings into flat pattern form, and to construct flat pattern drafting into three-dimensional form using Tessellation (creating a system/pattern out of many simple shapes of which the complexity lies in the relationship between units rather than each individual unit)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2a60c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a96191c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2e60c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1a60c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a96190e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Interdisciplinary","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

The fourth assignment is Interdisciplinary, developing student collaboration in project teams, establishing and fulfilling team responsibilities, contributing towards weekly discussions, observations about in-class exercises, independent research, reflections on studio assignments and practical activities. Students analyse, select, and conceptually integrate Tessellation into deployable structures and spatial enclosure for displaying their assignments in the Red Centre Gallery.

High Distinction and Distinction

Student is able to demonstrate a high degree of proficiency and marked improvement with their ability to translate drawings into flat pattern form, and to construct flat pattern drafting into three-dimensional form. Modify, manipulate and develop deployable structures and spatial enclosure at an advanced level. Classify all the principles and appropriate application and performance of construction materials, products, components, and assemblies, including their environmental impact and reuse.

Interdisciplinary responsibilities delegated fairly. Each member contributes in a valuable way to the project. All members always attend meetings and meet deadlines for deliverables. Team worked well together to achieve objectives. Members enjoyed interacting with each other and learned from each other. All data sources indicated a high level of mutual respect and collaboration.

Credit

Student is able to demonstrate a competent ability to translate drawings into flat pattern form, and to construct flat pattern drafting into three-dimensional form. Modify and manipulate deployable structures and spatial enclosure at an proficient level. Classify most of the principles and appropriate application and performance of construction materials, products, components, and assemblies, including their environmental impact and reuse.

Some minor inequities in the interdisciplinary delegation of responsibilities. Some members contribute more heavily than others but all members met their responsibilities. Members regularly attended meetings and deadlines for deliverables were met. Team worked well together most of the time, with only a few occurrences of communication breakdown or failure to collaborate when appropriate. Members were mostly respectful of each other.

Pass

Student demonstrates a basic ability to translate drawings into flat pattern form, and to construct flat pattern drafting into three-dimensional form. Modify and manipulate deployable structures and spatial enclosure at an elementary level. Classify some of the principles and appropriate application and performance of construction materials, products, components, and assemblies, including their environmental impact and reuse.

Apparent inequities in interdisciplinary delegation of responsibilities. Some members not meeting their responsibilities or not contributing in discussions. Team did not collaborate or communicate well. Some members would work independently, without regard to objectives or priorities and miss meetings, and/or deadlines. A lack of respect and regard was noted.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2e60c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6a60c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5260c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a961913","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Orthographic/parallel folds,","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Students analyse, select, and conceptually integrate 90 and 180 degrees Orthographic/parallel folds into a Deployable Structure for Architecture.

This assignment, developed from week-to-week exercises, involve student participation in the lectures and tutorials, allowing feedback and constructive criticism of their work in progress. The informal feedback assists students interpreting the assignment and achieving assessment objectives which evaluate their demonstrated ability to translate drawings into flat pattern form, and to construct flat pattern drafting into three-dimensional form using Tessellation (creating a system/pattern out of many simple shapes of which the complexity lies in the relationship between units rather than each individual unit)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2a60c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a96191c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2e60c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a660c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"de6081b3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Axonometric/equal angle folds and Isometric/unequal angle folds","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students translate 90 and 180 degree Axonometric/equal and Isometric/unequal angle folds to design a Spatial Enclosure for Interior Architecture.

This assignment, developed from week-to-week exercises, involve student participation in the lectures and tutorials, allowing feedback and constructive criticism of their work in progress. The informal feedback assists students interpreting the assignment and achieving assessment objectives which evaluate their demonstrated ability to translate drawings into flat pattern form, and to construct flat pattern drafting into three-dimensional form using Tessellation (creating a system/pattern out of many simple shapes of which the complexity lies in the relationship between units rather than each individual unit)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2a60c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a96191c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2e60c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6a60c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a660c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"de60c1b3db391c50eb6b147a3a961909","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BEIL0018.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

contentlets.description:
Kirigami  is a variation of origami that includes cutting of the paper (from Japanese "kiru" = to cut, "kami" = paper)

How can flat surfaces be transformed into useful three-dimensional structures? 

Kirigami patterns can be robustly manipulated into a variety of three-dimensional shapes by folding and cutting a flat surface into complex target configurations.

The course is designed to foster knowledge, understanding and skills that will assist the student with both future courses and professional design practice. Each class incorporates a range of teaching and learning strategies including demonstrations, studio exercises, hands-on making, and discussion. The basis of the exercises and assignments use folding and cutting to interpret the principles of each drawing skill: Orthographic/parallel folds, Axonometric/equal angle folds, Isometric/unequal angle folds and Parametric/pleat folds applied to span and parabola.

Skills covered in the course range from techniques of hand folding and physical model-building to presentation strategies and display systems. Weekly demonstrations and visual presentations address the conventions associated with modes of Architecture, Industrial Design, Interior and Landscape Architecture representation and their capacity to convey ideas.

Students, using DesignLab resources, classify the basic properties, appropriate application and performance of construction materials, products, components, and assemblies, including their environmental impact and reuse.
contentlets.title: Kirigami Architectural Principles & Creative Paper Engineering

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEIL0020 - International Construction Study Trip","description":"

This course is run jointly with two overseas universities, and comprises of two separate international study trips that students can choose from. The China trip is jointly run with Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST) in Wuhan and the Indonesian trip is jointly run with Petra Christian University in Surabaya.


UNSW students will visit China or Indonesia, where they will live near the host University’s campus and immerse themselves in the its learning activities. The course has three components. First, lectures where students learn about design and construction management principles and technologies applied in China or Indonesia. Second, site visits where students can immerse into the culture, architecture, technologies, methods, and site management of the Chinese or Indonesian construction industry. The site visits are tailored to complement the lectures. Third, cultural activities that students can participate in, such as learning batik technique, dancing, learning local language, and visiting historical sites.

Interdisciplinary student groups are tasked to prepare a maximum 5000-word portfolio on the impacts of local contexts on the design, architecture and construction practices in China/Indonesia and Australia.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"38185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"74185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b0185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f8185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"24185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual video reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

A 5- to 8-minute video showing key reflective learning from the lectures, site visits and cultural activities during the study trip. The content of the video must be aligned with and enhance the content of the individual reflective portfolio.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"38185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"74185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b0185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f8185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a0185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619af","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual travel diary","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

A maximum 3000-word report summarising the principles of each knowledge area covered in the course. Students should show evidence of their learning and demonstrate how the learning experience influences their understanding and is relevance to the industry context. Feedback will be given based on specified criteria, which include description of learning principles, critical thinking to demonstrate significance and implications of learning, and evidence of learning.

Issues in Urbanism","assoc_cl_id":"47f91177db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961997","assoc_short_title":"BENV6731 - Contemporary Issues in Urbanism","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/postgraduate/courses/2021/BENV6731","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"inactive","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"BENV6731","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"BEIL6000 - Mapping Social Justice in the City","description":"

This elective course is designed as a vehicle for the exploration of current interdisciplinary knowledge on social justice issues in Sydney. This course aims is a new blended learning course teaching ‘small data’ research and digital mapping skills, while also producing an online portal with ‘real world’ value. As well as the educational benefits of a course that produces a public resource of real social value, the focus on ‘small data’ skills addresses a weakness in the popular smart cities movement. Driven by the growth in computing power and big data sets, the smart cities movement often focuses on making use of available data, rather than developing new data sets. This often leads to a ‘streetlight’ effect, where researchers focus on issues that are easy to investigate, rather than those in most need of attention. This course will help to overcome this deficiency, by teaching students the importance of less visible issues, and providing the technological, social and spatial skills needed to bring these issues to light online. This course will introduce students to quick and effective technical methods for gathering spatial information and in turn, processing this information with geospatial and graphic tools to reveal patterns and produce maps. It will draw on materials from a range of disciplinary perspectives including urban planning, urban design, geography, architectural theory, sociology and media theory.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2cec993fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961912","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will submit a research-based report on their social justice topic area and should refer to the theories discussed in class and consider policies and grass-roots plans to overcome their social justice issue. The report must also include a detailed case study of their social justice topic in Sydney, outlining lessons for council that can be identified from their literature review. Detailed guidelines for the structure of the report will be available on Moodle, and the report should be primarily written work, although visual elements may be included if appropriate. The report must incorporate academic and other evidence-based research beyond the scope of the course readings, and use proper academic referencing.  Length – 1,500 words.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"14ec593fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d4ec593fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"04ec593fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961992","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Digital Map and Webpage","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"60","description":"

Webpage (30% group mark, 30% individual mark) – Students will design a webpage on their groups’ chosen social justice topic as part of the overall class website. The webpage needs to communicate the outcome of the group research in an easy to understand narrative. The webpage will include research from each group members’ individual research report, along with images, drawings or photographs as well as at least one (1) digital map designed and created by the group. As part of the assessment submission, students will need to outline their individual contribution. Detailed guidelines for the structure of the webpage will be available on Moodle and provided as a webpage template

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9cec593fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e8ec593fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"04ec593fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class and online participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Attendance","value":"attendance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Each student is expected to attend each day of face-to-face classes and to complete the class exercises outlined in the course schedule. The tutor will mark attendance each day and check the class exercises for each student have been completed (or attempted where exercises run on to the following day). Students are expected to post screenshots/documents of the work completed each day to the Moodle submission link to show work progress. Details for the participation requirements for each exercise will be provided in class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9cec593fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"80ec593fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961989","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

(10% individual mark) – Students should submit a brief, three-page (A4) research proposal outlining their research plan for the individual research report and digital map. The proposal will be in two sections: (1) the groups’ research topic, aims, proposed method and data collection, analysis and data visualization plan and expected findings, and (2) an individual breakdown of each group members’ personal contribution to the group research task.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"50ec593fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9cec593fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e8ec593fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c8ec593fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96198d","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BEIL6000.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

International Planning and Development","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/postgraduate/courses/2021/BENV6701","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"inactive","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"BENV6701","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"BEIL6001 - International Planning","description":"

The primary purpose of this course is to introduce students to relevant concepts of planning that look beyond the Australian context to that of the developing societies of our world. The course looks at some of the following topic areas in detail: International Planning and Development (IPD) theory within its historical context, exploration of current thinking on development policy, a critical examination of merits of the delivery of 'aid' by various bodies focusing on the role of international government agencies and non governmental agencies, an in-depth examination of built environment delivery agents such as the private sector and national governments will be further examined, an analysis and assessment of the function of planning in the post disaster context to note distinctions between emergency relief and development, the application of theoretical knowledge to real world environments. Interwoven into the above topics will be an appreciation of gender within developing societies.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ad8d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96195f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project Outline (Group assessment)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

All students, working in groups of five, are required to submit a group project proposal of two pages (maximum) on a given topic, connected with a particularly difficult or complex development project or issue from a country in the global South. Group project topics involving social, political, environmental and economic considerations will be identified and allocated by the instructor. Each group is expected to unpack project components and develop a project proposal consist of 2 pages comprising:

 

• Project Title

• Up to 1 page of narrative summarising your project which sets out objectives, scope and data

sources, and expected method you will use;

• Half a page outline of the structure of your project

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"518d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d98d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"708d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96191e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay: Individual Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Each student will be given an individual assignment topic (topics will be posted on Moodle) to write a 2,000 word essay on a particular issues on development of the countries of the global south. There will be separate assignments for Undergraduate and Graduate students.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"518d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"558d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"918d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d98d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"898d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961922","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project Presentation. 10% (group mark) 20% (individual mark)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

10% (group mark)

20% (individual mark)

Each group will prepare a Power Point Presentation and present it to an invited guest panel members who would ask questions and discuss the project with you. Each group to prepare two questions to ask the other groups.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"518d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"558d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"918d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"898d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961933","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project report. 10% (group mark) 20% (individual mark)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

10% (group mark)
20% (individual mark)

Prepare a well-argued and well-organised project report by way of answering the questions raised and discussed, of no more than 5,000 words (including tables but excluding appendices and references), illustrated and with all quotations and concepts fully referenced to the Author, Date and Page from which they are drawn, using the Harvard (Author Date) System, with illustrations captioned and accurately sourced (for further details see ‘Outline Guide to Referencing your Work’, below).. Your project must be clearly written in your own words, and illustrated. You must base your research and writing on a predominance of scholarly and professional sources, i.e. books, journals, theses, reports, newspaper articles.

International Planning and Development","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2021/BENV6701","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"inactive","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"BENV6701","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"BEIL6001 - International Planning","description":"

The primary purpose of this course is to introduce students to relevant concepts of planning that look beyond the Australian context to that of the developing societies of our world. The course looks at some of the following topic areas in detail: International Planning and Development (IPD) theory within its historical context, exploration of current thinking on development policy, a critical examination of merits of the delivery of 'aid' by various bodies focusing on the role of international government agencies and non governmental agencies, an in-depth examination of built environment delivery agents such as the private sector and national governments will be further examined, an analysis and assessment of the function of planning in the post disaster context to note distinctions between emergency relief and development, the application of theoretical knowledge to real world environments. Interwoven into the above topics will be an appreciation of gender within developing societies.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ad8d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96195f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project Outline (Group assessment)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

All students, working in groups of five, are required to submit a group project proposal of two pages (maximum) on a given topic, connected with a particularly difficult or complex development project or issue from a country in the global South. Group project topics involving social, political, environmental and economic considerations will be identified and allocated by the instructor. Each group is expected to unpack project components and develop a project proposal consist of 2 pages comprising:

 

• Project Title

• Up to 1 page of narrative summarising your project which sets out objectives, scope and data

sources, and expected method you will use;

• Half a page outline of the structure of your project

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"518d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d98d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"708d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96191e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay: Individual Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Each student will be given an individual assignment topic (topics will be posted on Moodle) to write a 2,000 word essay on a particular issues on development of the countries of the global south. There will be separate assignments for Undergraduate and Graduate students.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"518d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"558d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"918d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d98d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"898d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961922","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project Presentation. 10% (group mark) 20% (individual mark)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

10% (group mark)

20% (individual mark)

Each group will prepare a Power Point Presentation and present it to an invited guest panel members who would ask questions and discuss the project with you. Each group to prepare two questions to ask the other groups.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"518d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"558d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"918d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"898d95bfdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961933","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project report. 10% (group mark) 20% (individual mark)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

10% (group mark)
20% (individual mark)

Prepare a well-argued and well-organised project report by way of answering the questions raised and discussed, of no more than 5,000 words (including tables but excluding appendices and references), illustrated and with all quotations and concepts fully referenced to the Author, Date and Page from which they are drawn, using the Harvard (Author Date) System, with illustrations captioned and accurately sourced (for further details see ‘Outline Guide to Referencing your Work’, below).. Your project must be clearly written in your own words, and illustrated. You must base your research and writing on a predominance of scholarly and professional sources, i.e. books, journals, theses, reports, newspaper articles.

This course reviews the principles of urban design and guides students through urban design methodology via a series of small design projects. Teaching is through "enquiry by design" whereby lectures, site visits and case studies assist students' learning and development through the exploration of design projects of varying scales and contexts (e.g. town centres, concept designs for specific sites, structure plans). 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4488e9bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1 - Urban Design Readings","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Assignment 1 – Urban Design Readings & Techniques (Individual - 30%). 

Students will prepare a well referenced and illustrated summary of one of the readings, as well as analyse an urban area using to-scale plans, sections, elevations and photographs. The readings for this course will help build an understanding of urban design theory and the lectures/ tutorials will assist in developing urban design techniques.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0c88e9bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bf78e9bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6778e9bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2 - Investigative Analysis and Conclusions","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Assignment 2 – Urban Design Analysis (Group - 15%)

Working in teams and using existing information from local councils, websites or other relevant sources, students will prepare a base plan of the selected precinct. The process will require students to participate with their team, mapping and interpreting the selected area as well as plot their analysis on base maps of an identifiable scale. The site investigation and analysis should identify the characteristics of the precinct and arrive at conclusions/ urban design principles based on observations and findings, as well as learnings from lectures, readings and tutorials.

Assignment 3 – UD Structure & Block Plan (Group - 15% and Individual - 40%)

As a group, students will prepare a precinct structure plan that identifies the street network, public domain, transport connections and social infrastructure. The team will propose development parcels/ subdivision pattern, street sections and building types to inform future development controls of height, yield use and density.

Individually students will prepare a Master Plan of an urban block consistent with the Precinct Structure Plan or an equivalent Urban Design Brief.

Teaching is through "enquiry by design" whereby lectures, site visits and case studies assist students' learning and development through the exploration of design projects of varying scales and contexts (e.g. town centres, concept designs for specific sites, structure plans).
