This course reviews the principles of urban design and guides students through urban design methodology via a series of small design projects. Teaching is through "enquiry by design" whereby lectures, site visits and case studies assist students' learning and development through the exploration of design projects of varying scales and contexts (e.g. town centres, concept designs for specific sites, structure plans). 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4488e9bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1 - Urban Design Readings","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Assignment 1 – Urban Design Readings & Techniques (Individual - 30%). 

Students will prepare a well referenced and illustrated summary of one of the readings, as well as analyse an urban area using to-scale plans, sections, elevations and photographs. The readings for this course will help build an understanding of urban design theory and the lectures/ tutorials will assist in developing urban design techniques.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0c88e9bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bf78e9bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6778e9bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2 - Investigative Analysis and Conclusions","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Assignment 2 – Urban Design Analysis (Group - 15%)

Working in teams and using existing information from local councils, websites or other relevant sources, students will prepare a base plan of the selected precinct. The process will require students to participate with their team, mapping and interpreting the selected area as well as plot their analysis on base maps of an identifiable scale. The site investigation and analysis should identify the characteristics of the precinct and arrive at conclusions/ urban design principles based on observations and findings, as well as learnings from lectures, readings and tutorials.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0c88e9bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b378e9bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cc88e9bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ee","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"af78e9bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3 - UD Structure Plan (team) Individual UD component (individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"55","description":"

Assignment 3 – UD Structure & Block Plan (Group - 15% and Individual - 40%)

As a group, students will prepare a precinct structure plan that identifies the street network, public domain, transport connections and social infrastructure. The team will propose development parcels/ subdivision pattern, street sections and building types to inform future development controls of height, yield use and density.

Individually students will prepare a Master Plan of an urban block consistent with the Precinct Structure Plan or an equivalent Urban Design Brief.

contentlets.description: Cinema is an art form closely tied to architecture and the built environment. They both create and define experiences of place and space. The video camera is an easy and highly accessible tool that provides for creative expression, storytelling, documentary, research and critique of spaces within the built environment. It enables the creation of cinematic experiences for distribution to a wide audience through the web or other forms of multimedia.The aim of this course is to explore the video camera and cinema in the understanding, evaluating and communication of place and space. It also aims to make the video camera a familiar tool in architectural research and analysis. The course will culminate in the final assessment which is the production of a short film, employing creative ideas and techniques, as well as critical analysis, to effectively tell a story about a selected spatial experience.
contentlets.title: Cinematic Space

It also aims to make the video camera a familiar tool in architectural research and analysis. The course will culminate in the final assessment which is the production of a short film, employing creative ideas and techniques, as well as critical analysis, to effectively tell a story about a selected spatial experience.

Researching Art, Architecture and Design","description":"

The course is offered under the auspices of the Built Environment Interdisciplinary Learning initiative [BEIL] and is open to all students in the Faculty of the Built Environment who have completed at least 96UOC. The courses in this suite are operated independently by their programs, but in parallel, building on the synergies for seeking research grants, generating learning and teaching opportunities, and attracting funding and sponsorship.


This interdisciplinary course offers students an opportunity to work within a collaborative, interdisciplinary environment which draws on students’ disciplinary knowledge and provides students with new skills and knowledge for approaching interdisciplinary projects. Students work together in multidisciplinary teams to research and interpret a variety of public art projects, and to contextualise these projects within professional built environment practice.

contentlets.description:
The course is offered under the auspices of the Built Environment Interdisciplinary Learning initiative [BEIL] and is open to all students in the Faculty of the Built Environment who have completed at least 96UOC. The courses in this suite are operated independently by their programs, but in parallel, building on the synergies for seeking research grants, generating learning and teaching opportunities, and attracting funding and sponsorship.

This interdisciplinary course offers students an opportunity to work within a collaborative, interdisciplinary environment which draws on students’ disciplinary knowledge and provides students with new skills and knowledge for approaching interdisciplinary projects. Students work together in multidisciplinary teams to research and interpret a variety of public art projects, and to contextualise these projects within professional built environment practice.

contentlets.keywords: be interdisciplinary learning,research in art and design history; australian art and design historiography;visual archival researc
contentlets.description:
The course is offered under the auspices of the Built Environment Interdisciplinary Learning initiative [BEIL] and is open to all students in the Faculty of the Built Environment who have completed at least 96UOC. The courses in this suite are operated independently by their programs, but in parallel, building on the synergies for seeking research grants, generating learning and teaching opportunities, and attracting funding and sponsorship.

This interdisciplinary course offers students an opportunity to work within a collaborative, interdisciplinary environment which draws on students’ disciplinary knowledge and provides students with new skills and knowledge for approaching interdisciplinary projects. Students work together in multidisciplinary teams to research and interpret a variety of public art projects, and to contextualise these projects within professional built environment practice.
contentlets.title: Researching Art, Architecture and Design

Heritage Planning","description":"

This course provides students with an overview of the theory and practice of heritage planning. Focused
predominately within NSW and metropolitan Sydney, the course will, however, explore heritage planning in Australia
at World, National, State and Local levels.
By undertaking Heritage Planning you will develop your appreciation and understanding of the physical and nonphysical
aspects of Australia’s heritage. The course will provide you with an introduction to the various statues that
apply to heritage within Australia and NSW. During the first half of the semester, we will cover the history of heritage
conservation in Australia, including the ICOMOS Burra Charter, and how heritage is identified, assessed and
managed at World, National, Commonwealth, and State and Local levels. Following mid-semester break, our focus
shifts and we concentrate on different aspects of our heritage including; cultural landscapes, Aboriginal and settler
archaeology, built heritage, cultural landscapes, interpretation and intangible values. Throughout the course you will
learn from experienced professionals working in the public and private sectors. They will present various disciplinary
perspectives including archaeology, architecture and landscape architecture. The guest lecturers will talk about their
‘real life’ experience of working in heritage in the context of the legislation and urban development in Sydney and
elsewhere.


Drawing on this professional experience, the course will canvass some of the different approaches to understanding
heritage and conservation. Many of these approaches are political and official, involving governments at international,
national, state and local levels. They are also formal and involve statutory planning processes such as identification,
assessment, listing via planning instruments and heritage registers, and provisions for permits and applications. In
each case, the approaches, solutions and outcomes for heritage projects vary based on political will, economic
issues, the formal protective mechanisms, professional judgments, subjectivity and community values.
The primary aim of the course is to ensure that as future professionals in the fields of urban planning, architecture and
landscape architecture, you develop a sound understanding of the theoretical, legislative, administrative and practical
aspects of heritage conservation that is grounded in ‘real world experience’. This, in turn, will enable you to gain an
understanding of how heritage and the values attributed to it change through time and reflect how we see ourselves
as a nation, a state, a community and as individuals.

The place you choose may already be classified by the National Trust, listed on a Local
Environmental Plan or the Australia Heritage Database. Follow the 5 steps outlined on the Heritage
Website. http://www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_19.htm and use the heritage guidelines to assist you.
You may also find it helpful to look at the listings for items that are already listed on the SHR.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"205cd1fbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6c5cd1fbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b85cd1fbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"185c91fbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Heritage report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

Prepare a Heritage Impact Statement for a development project in a Local Government
Area of your choice. The HIS must be prepared with reference to the Heritage Guidelines. (2,500 – 3000
words). (See http://www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/03_index.htm#impact)

Heritage Planning","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2021/BENV2943","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"inactive","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"BENV2943","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"BEIL6006 - Heritage Planning","description":"

This course provides students with an overview of the theory and practice of heritage planning. Focused
predominately within NSW and metropolitan Sydney, the course will, however, explore heritage planning in Australia
at World, National, State and Local levels.
By undertaking Heritage Planning you will develop your appreciation and understanding of the physical and nonphysical
aspects of Australia’s heritage. The course will provide you with an introduction to the various statues that
apply to heritage within Australia and NSW. During the first half of the semester, we will cover the history of heritage
conservation in Australia, including the ICOMOS Burra Charter, and how heritage is identified, assessed and
managed at World, National, Commonwealth, and State and Local levels. Following mid-semester break, our focus
shifts and we concentrate on different aspects of our heritage including; cultural landscapes, Aboriginal and settler
archaeology, built heritage, cultural landscapes, interpretation and intangible values. Throughout the course you will
learn from experienced professionals working in the public and private sectors. They will present various disciplinary
perspectives including archaeology, architecture and landscape architecture. The guest lecturers will talk about their
‘real life’ experience of working in heritage in the context of the legislation and urban development in Sydney and
elsewhere.


Drawing on this professional experience, the course will canvass some of the different approaches to understanding
heritage and conservation. Many of these approaches are political and official, involving governments at international,
national, state and local levels. They are also formal and involve statutory planning processes such as identification,
assessment, listing via planning instruments and heritage registers, and provisions for permits and applications. In
each case, the approaches, solutions and outcomes for heritage projects vary based on political will, economic
issues, the formal protective mechanisms, professional judgments, subjectivity and community values.
The primary aim of the course is to ensure that as future professionals in the fields of urban planning, architecture and
landscape architecture, you develop a sound understanding of the theoretical, legislative, administrative and practical
aspects of heritage conservation that is grounded in ‘real world experience’. This, in turn, will enable you to gain an
understanding of how heritage and the values attributed to it change through time and reflect how we see ourselves
as a nation, a state, a community and as individuals.

The place you choose may already be classified by the National Trust, listed on a Local
Environmental Plan or the Australia Heritage Database. Follow the 5 steps outlined on the Heritage
Website. http://www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_19.htm and use the heritage guidelines to assist you.
You may also find it helpful to look at the listings for items that are already listed on the SHR.

Area of your choice. The HIS must be prepared with reference to the Heritage Guidelines. (2,500 – 3000
words). (See http://www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/03_index.htm#impact)

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEIL6007 - International Study Tour","description":"

Affordable housing is a basic requirement and an essential ingredient of a just, inclusive and sustainable city. With the low housing affordability in Sydney it is of paramount importance that the students of architecture, interior architecture, construction, planning and landscape architecture are introduced to models of affordable housing that are accessible to the majority of the city’s population. The BEIL6007 International Engagement Housing in Vienna course takes the students to the city of Vienna where more than 60% of the city’s population lives in some form of subsidized apartments. The Viennese model of affordable housing is built on a diverse definition of social and affordable housing that includes city-owned flats and limited profit housing co-operatives.


The Housing in Vienna course is offered to a maximum number of 25 students currently enrolled in third year Architectural Studies and Master of Architecture and Planning, and third and fourth year in Interior Architecture, Construction, Landscape, and Planning. The course takes place at the Technical University of Vienna where UNSW students collaborate with local students and practitioners.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4c282d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Sydney social housing examples","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Sydney social housing examples: 6-minute video groups from diverse disciplinary backgrounds.

20% Group work, Individual assessment

 

Type: Preparation at UNSW: Upon enrolment in the course at UNSW, the students will partake in several teaching sessions that will introduce them to the subject matter, selected readings and prepare for the site trip to Vienna.

Prior to going to Vienna, the following tasks need to be completed:

  1. 5 to 7 min video on social housing in Sydney.
    This task is to be done in groups of 3 to 4 students. The video needs to present an example/ case study of a social housing project in Sydney. There are many examples in Sydney and some are local to UNSW- such as Daceyville; Malabar/ Bilga Crescent, Little Bay Namatjira housing etc. The video needs to cover the history and context of the project and can focus on a topic of group’s choice. The videos will be shown and presented by UNSW students to our TU Vienna colleagues.

All videos must be uploaded on Moodle by TBC date.

 

  1. The students need to become familiar with the historical, social and political context of Viennese housing inclusive of planning regulations and selected competition details – through the readings available on Moodle. [no formal assessment]

 

Weighting: 20%

Type: Group work, individual assessment

Description: Multimedia / video

Feedback process: Discussion and review by staff and students

Travel diary: annotated drawings, photographs and diagrams identifying the relationships between broader urban and planning issues and the specific design typologies. The discussion needs to encompass policies and strategic frameworks in their relation to urban and architectural propositions.

Type: Vienna field trip: Structured around visits to the key locations of affordable housing which are considered some of the most significant architectural sites in Vienna. The field trips will be organised and conducted with the support of TU Vienna staff and students. UNSW students will record the site visits in their travel diaries. The travel diaries will be submitted for assessment upon their return to UNSW. 

 

Due: TBC. Mark 50% Submit on Moodle

 

Weighting: 50%

Type: Individual submission

Description: On site analysis of precedents, recording and research. Submission format: A4 landscape  

Feedback process: Staff feedback

Type: Workshop: UNSW students will work with the TU Vienna students in groups on the projects focused on affordable housing in Vienna.

Due: Group work to be completed in Vienna.

Submit on Moodle, TBC [digitally submitted – online]

 

Mark 30% [group work]

 

Type: Group work  

Description: Project based.

Feedback process: Peer critique and staff feedback

The BEIL International Design Studio is a course that will be offered once per year as part of the Built Environment Interdisciplinary Learning (BEIL) suite of courses. Each year a host city will be offered that is suitable for students from all undergraduate BE programs with at least 96UoC completed and BE postgraduate students. This course will provide students with a unique opportunity to work with students from other programs in interdisciplinary teams, in a design studio format.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"BEIL6009","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEIL6009 - Integrated Building Design Case Studies","description":"

This course will focus on the Sydney Opera House (SOH) as a landmark case-study to explore the key role of interdisciplinary collaboration (IC) and integrated building design (IBD) in the achievement of high performance architecture (HPA). HPA describes buildings that exceed design, environmental, social and economic standards to achieve sustainable urban environments of the future. This course reflects a view that professional practice within the built environment field will require advanced levels of communication and new knowledge to support ongoing development of disciplinary identity, interdisciplinary collaboration and the ability to comprehend and navigate complexity and interdependency in large-scale projects within rapidly changing urban environments. Drawing on their disciplinary knowledge and through experiential site and archive visits, lectures and online resources, individually and in groups, students of diverse disciplinary backgrounds will critically engage with the role of IC and IBD in the achievement of HPA with a focus on the SOH.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a541a13bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961992","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A-1 6-minute group power point presentation:","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

6-minute group power point presentation: in groups of two from diverse disciplinary backgrounds, select two professional project participants (e.g., engineer and architect). Analyse their respective contributions and describe the challenges and merits of interdisciplinary collaboration in relation to the SOH.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5141a13bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961989","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9541a13bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96196d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e941a13bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4d41a13bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A-2 Submit an individual personal diary","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Submit an individual personal diary (consisting of at least 10 distinct entries) of drawings, annotated sketches and short reflective written statements recording your immersive and critical engagement with an aspect or aspects of the design, delivery and operation of the SOH and its relationship to interdisciplinarity.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5141a13bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961989","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9541a13bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96196d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8541a13bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A-3 20-minute simulated “project control group”","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

in the prior groups of 4 students and with your course lecturer, undertake a 20-minute simulated “project control group” (PCG) meeting scenario in which disciplinary roles and collaborative strategies regarding a complex, public building project are discussed. Individual grade.

contentlets.description:
This course considers the city as a site of inquiry, experimentation, and collaboration. Students in the course will be looking at how some of Sydney’s biggest urban challenges can be addressed through design interventions at the local scale. Key themes to be examined include strategic planning, city-shaping infrastructure and pressing concerns of densification, housing affordability, gentrification, as well as social and spatial inequality.

Through a series of intensive design workshops, accompanied by lectures, tours and site visits, the students will be introduced to key government, professional and community stakeholders. The course will be structured as an intense 10-day design studio workshop that will foster design innovation between disciplines, while also providing connections to local industry, issues and practice. The focus is on how to implement the key strategic directions set out in Sydney’s latest Metropolitan and District Plans. The big urban challenges faced, and Government proposals to solve them, will be explored through focused design projects at the local level. Working in multidisciplinary groups, students will be asked to use real-life scenarios to test their ideas and directly engage with key community and professional stakeholders through the design process.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEIL6011 - Street Life Studies: Sydney Phnom Penh","description":"

Street Life Studies: Cambodia is an international, interdisciplinary urban design elective that places you, the student, on the streets of Phnom Penh and Sydney in collaboration with your Cambodian design colleagues. In these contrasting contexts, you will use quick hand drawing, data collection and digital post-production techniques to observe and analyse the dynamic layers of public street space: physical, behavioural and systematic. This on-field research will be used as evidence for the creation of an urban design proposal in response to a real-world challenge you have observed in the street sites. The proposal will focus on contributing to the creation of people-centred public street space that is vital and inclusive.


Phnom Penh streets are clear examples of diverse urban dwellers appropriating the public domain. In many Sydney streets, this kind of informal or unplanned activity is less apparent. What knowledge can be exchanged in comparing these contexts? How can we use interdisciplinary and intercultural collaboration to expand this? How can we draw from both the formal and informal dynamics of street space? How might we as designers use observational research methodologies to meaningfully contribute to place-making processes?


This course runs across the December/January summer session and is open to undergraduate and postgraduate Built Environment students. Application is via an online EOI process followed by formal enrollment. Travel grants and financial support can be applied for however availability changes each year. Please contact the course convener for details. Further information and previous years coursework can be found at www.streetlifestudies.wordpress.com.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"04185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96194f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"ANALYSE: street observations (individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

30%  Assessment 1a: street observations location 1

30%  Assessment 1b: street observations location 2


Assessment description:

Observe, document, deconstruct and interpret, the urban dynamics of two comparative street spaces: one local, one international. Examine a nominated set of components covering the spatial, systematic and human layers of each street environment. Students will extrapolate driving forces, synthesise information to find recurring themes, and compare findings between locations.

To complete this assessment, students will base themselves in each street space, observing patterns over varied periods of the day and night, and engaging with its users. A series of texts will be used to further the analysis. 

Information will be communicated using hand drawing, digital post production and text. 

Feedback process:

Street observations will be presented to tutors and colleagues for feedback.

Assessment Criteria:

- Identification of required urban elements

- Analysis, synthesis and interpretation of information

- Visual and verbal communication



","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"08185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7f085133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8c185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c8185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2b081133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"PROPOSE: urban intervention (individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

30% Assessment 2: urban intervention

Assessment description:

Based on street observation exercises, identify an urban challenge faced in the sites studied and develop an urban design intervention that addresses this challenge. 

Feedback process:

Urban Interventions will be pitched to tutors, colleagues and street users for feedback. 

Assessment Criteria:

- Use of street observations as evidence to inform urban intervention

- Execution and implementation of idea

- Visual and verbal communication

 ","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7f085133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8c185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bb085133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c8185133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"63081133db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"COLLABORATE","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

5% Assessment 3a: group research location 1
5% Assessment 3b: group research location 2

Assessment description:
Drawing on disciplinary skills and knowledge, work in small groups to critically analyse each location. Communicate this process work to the class in a short, 'pecha kucha' presentation. This work is formative in directly contributing towards the Street Observations and Urban Interventions assessment tasks.


Feedback process:
Analysis will be informally presented to tutors and colleagues.

Assessment criteria 

- Application of individual disciplinary knowledge 

- Synthesis of diverse knowledge streams

- Collaboration (peer assessment)

5% Assessment 3a: group research location 1
5% Assessment 3b: group research location 2

Assessment description:
Drawing on disciplinary skills and knowledge, work in small groups to critically analyse each location. Communicate this process work to the class in a short, 'pecha kucha' presentation. This work is formative in directly contributing towards the Street Observations and Urban Interventions assessment tasks.


Feedback process:
Analysis will be informally presented to tutors and colleagues.

Assessment criteria 

- Application of individual disciplinary knowledge 

- Synthesis of diverse knowledge streams

- Collaboration (peer assessment)

contentlets.keywords: be interdisciplinary learning,streets,public space,urban design,city making,participatory design,place making,urbanism,multi disciplinary,international,developing cities,cross-cultural,human-focused design,hand drawing,urban sketching,community engagement,urban challenges,real world,on-field research
contentlets.description:
Street Life Studies: Cambodia is an international, interdisciplinary urban design elective that places you, the student, on the streets of Phnom Penh and Sydney in collaboration with your Cambodian design colleagues. In these contrasting contexts, you will use quick hand drawing, data collection and digital post-production techniques to observe and analyse the dynamic layers of public street space: physical, behavioural and systematic. This on-field research will be used as evidence for the creation of an urban design proposal in response to a real-world challenge you have observed in the street sites. The proposal will focus on contributing to the creation of people-centred public street space that is vital and inclusive.

Phnom Penh streets are clear examples of diverse urban dwellers appropriating the public domain. In many Sydney streets, this kind of informal or unplanned activity is less apparent. What knowledge can be exchanged in comparing these contexts? How can we use interdisciplinary and intercultural collaboration to expand this? How can we draw from both the formal and informal dynamics of street space? How might we as designers use observational research methodologies to meaningfully contribute to place-making processes?

This course runs across the December/January summer session and is open to undergraduate and postgraduate Built Environment students. Application is via an online EOI process followed by formal enrollment. Travel grants and financial support can be applied for however availability changes each year. Please contact the course convener for details. Further information and previous years coursework can be found at www.streetlifestudies.wordpress.com.
contentlets.title: Street Life Studies: Sydney Phnom Penh

Situated in a real-world international setting, students will collaborate in interdisciplinary and intercultural teams to investigate pressing challenges of urbanisation (SDG 11 ‘Sustainable Cities and Communities’). Students will critically analyse a specific socio-spatial context, identifying an urbanisation challenge. They will use this analysis to propose an ethically grounded response through the evaluation of goals, methods and potential consequences.

This course will allow students to develop and apply disciplinary knowledge whilst building capabilities as global citizens (SDG 4.7.1) that enable practice across disciplinary and cultural boundaries. The UNESCO Global Citizenship Education guideline (2015) will be used as a framework to build knowledge, skills and values that shape students who are “informed and critically literate, ethically responsible and engaged, socially connected and respectful of diversity”.

In this assessment, you will critically analyse a cross-disciplinary urbanisation challenge and its socio-spatial context. You will examine this in a real-world international geographic context. In the analysis, you will both apply your disciplinary expertise and bring together diverse perspectives. To foster this, you will begin with a broad analysis working in interdisciplinary and intercultural teams. You will use self-reflection to evaluate your international and interdisciplinary learnings against the UNESCO learning domains of cognitive, socio-emotional and behavioural awareness.

 

Part 1: Broad analysis: teamwork, one collective output

Assessment criteria

30% Collaboration (team evaluation - self/peer review)            

10% Self-reflection (journal post/blog)

In this assessment, you will propose action in response to the critical analysis and ethical reasoning surrounding the urbanisation challenge identified. Your proposed action will be developed individually however you will continue to work in your teams to collectively evaluate the goals, methods, and potential consequences of your proposed action. You will use self-reflection to evaluate your international and interdisciplinary learnings against the UNESCO learning domains of cognitive, socio-emotional and behavioural awareness.

Propose action based on analysis: individual output, teamwork to support formative tasks

Assessment criteria

10% Self-reflection (journal post/blog)

In this assessment, you will propose action in response to the critical analysis and ethical reasoning surrounding the urbanisation challenge identified. Your proposed action will be developed individually however you will continue to work in your teams to collectively evaluate the goals, methods, and potential consequences of your proposed action. You will use self-reflection to evaluate your international and interdisciplinary learnings against the UNESCO learning domains of cognitive, socio-emotional and behavioural awareness.

Propose action based on analysis: individual output, teamwork to support formative tasks

contentlets.description:
Situated in a real-world international setting, students will collaborate in interdisciplinary and intercultural teams to investigate pressing challenges of urbanisation (SDG 11 ‘Sustainable Cities and Communities’). Students will critically analyse a specific socio-spatial context, identifying an urbanisation challenge. They will use this analysis to propose an ethically grounded response through the evaluation of goals, methods and potential consequences.

This course will allow students to develop and apply disciplinary knowledge whilst building capabilities as global citizens (SDG 4.7.1) that enable practice across disciplinary and cultural boundaries. The UNESCO Global Citizenship Education guideline (2015) will be used as a framework to build knowledge, skills and values that shape students who are “informed and critically literate, ethically responsible and engaged, socially connected and respectful of diversity”.
contentlets.title: BE Nomad
